skill.name: git-workflow
skill.description: Git best practices for commits, branches, pull requests, and collaboration workflows following Conventional Commits and GitFlow patterns
skill.summary: Professional Git workflow automation for clean commits and effective team collaboration
skill.author: AI-Vibe-Prompts

security_audit.summary: This skill is a pure documentation resource teaching Git workflow best practices. All static findings are false positives from pattern matching on instructional markdown content. The skill contains no executable code, no network requests, and no security risks.

content.user_title: Automate Professional Git Workflows with Claude Code
content.value_statement: Managing Git commits and branches manually leads to messy history and collaboration issues. This skill automates Git best practices using Conventional Commits and GitFlow patterns for clean, professional version control.
actual_capabilities: Auto-format commit messages following Conventional Commits standard with type, scope, and subject
Generate standardized branch names using ticket IDs and descriptive patterns
Guide GitFlow workflow implementation including feature, release, and hotfix branches
Provide pre-commit checklists to prevent secrets and ensure code quality gates
Validate commit message structure and enforce team conventions
Auto-invoke when Git-related keywords are detected in user requests
limitations: Does not execute Git commands directly, only provides guidance and formatting
Requires user to configure team-specific conventions and ticket ID patterns
Cannot enforce policies without integration with Git hooks or CI/CD systems
Does not replace comprehensive code review processes or security scanning

use_cases.title: Standardize Team Commit Messages
use_cases.description: Ensure all developers follow Conventional Commits format for automated changelog generation and semantic versioning. The skill auto-formats commit messages with proper types, scopes, and subjects.

use_cases.title: Implement GitFlow for Release Management
use_cases.description: Guide teams through proper branch creation for features, releases, and hotfixes. The skill provides step-by-step GitFlow patterns for merging to main and develop branches.

use_cases.title: Prevent Accidental Secret Commits
use_cases.description: Run pre-commit security checks to detect API keys, passwords, and secrets before they enter version control. The skill provides grep patterns and quality gate commands.

output_examples.input: Format this commit: added user login with Google OAuth
output_examples.output:
feat(auth): add OAuth2 Google login support

Follows Conventional Commits format:
- Type: feat (new feature)
- Scope: auth (authentication module)
- Subject: imperative mood, lowercase

output_examples.input: Create a branch name for implementing shopping cart checkout, ticket ECOM-456
output_examples.output:
feature/ECOM-456-shopping-cart-checkout

Follows pattern: <type>/<ticket-id>-<description>
- Type: feature (new functionality)
- Ticket: ECOM-456 (for traceability)
- Description: kebab-case, descriptive

output_examples.input: Show me how to check for secrets before committing
output: npm run lint && npm run typecheck && npm run test
This detects common secret patterns and runs quality gates to prevent issues.

best_practices: Always use imperative mood in commit subjects. Write add user authentication not added user authentication for consistency with Git-generated messages.
Include ticket IDs in branch names for traceability. Pattern feature/TICKET-123-description enables automatic linking to project management tools.
Run pre-commit security checks to detect secrets. Use grep patterns for API keys and passwords before code enters version control history.
anti_patterns: Do not use vague commit messages like fix bug or update code. These provide no context for future developers or automated tools.
Avoid committing directly to main or develop branches. Always use feature branches and pull requests for code review and CI/CD validation.
Never skip pre-commit quality gates to save time. Broken tests or secrets in commits create technical debt that is expensive to fix later.

faq.question: Does this skill automatically commit my code?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance and formatting for Git workflows. You retain full control over when and what to commit. The skill helps format messages and suggests commands.

faq.question: Can I customize the commit message format for my team?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill follows Conventional Commits by default but you can request custom formats. Describe your team conventions and the skill will adapt its guidance accordingly.

faq.question: Does this work with GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill teaches standard Git workflows that work with all Git hosting platforms. The branch naming and commit conventions are platform-agnostic.

faq.question: How does the auto-invoke feature work?
faq.answer: The skill activates automatically when you mention Git-related keywords like commit, branch, push, or pull request. This provides proactive workflow guidance without manual skill invocation.

faq.question: Will this skill prevent me from committing secrets?
faq.answer: The skill provides grep commands to detect common secret patterns before committing. However, you must run these commands yourself. For automated enforcement, integrate Git hooks or CI/CD security scanners.

faq.question: Can this skill help with merge conflicts?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill auto-invokes when you mention merge conflicts and can guide you through resolution strategies. It provides GitFlow patterns for proper merging between branches.
